awd_abstract_narration:
A geometric manifold is an abstract mathematical object designed to model the space we live in. The concept also encompasses the notion of a space-time in the theory of relativity, as well as phase spaces, configuration spaces, and other useful structures in physics. While empirical physics is dedicated to measuring the precise features (e.g. shape, size, etc.) of our universe, the question of what possible features could the universe have, subject to certain laws, is a mathematical one. The data comprising the answer to such a question is called a moduli space; it is a topological space whose points are the possible geometric manifolds of a certain type and whose topology organizes those geometric manifolds into families whose features vary continuously. This project addresses important questions about many different classes of low-dimensional geometric manifolds and their moduli. The main focus is the study of manifolds modeled on real projective geometry and affine geometry, two classical geometries with just the right amount of symmetry to allow for large interesting moduli spaces with mysterious but tractable behavior.

This project weaves together ideas from a cross-section of mathematics and physics, including geometry, topology, group theory, dynamics, and relativity. A recently introduced notion of convex cocompactness for discrete subgroups of the real projective general linear group acting on projective space extends the definition of classical convex cocompact Kleinian groups and other examples, but is general enough to describe large open regions in the space of finitely generated discrete groups that were left unexplored by other methods.  A connection has been identified between this notion and Labourie's notion of Anosov subgroup, and the convex cocompact subgroups studied here involve many interesting deformation space for non-hyperbolic discrete subgroups. Another line of work studies Margulis spacetimes as geometric limits of anti de Sitter spacetimes, with consequences for geometry, topology, and deformation theory.  Connections between hyperbolic and anti de Sitter geometry in dimension three are particularly promising.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
A geometric manifold is an abstract mathematical object designed to model the space we live in. The concept also encompasses the notion of a space-time in the theory of relativity, as well as phase spaces, configuration spaces, and other useful structures in physics. While empirical physics is dedicated to measuring the precise features (e.g. shape, size, etc.) of our universe, the question of what possible features could the universe have, subject to certain laws, is a mathematical one. The data comprising the answer to such a question is called a moduli space; it is a topological space whose points are the possible geometric manifolds of a certain type and whose topology organizes those geometric manifolds into families whose features vary continuously. 

 

Over the course of the grant, the PI obtained new results on several different classes of low-dimensional geometric manifolds and their moduli. The main focus was the study of manifolds modeled on real projective geometry, a classical geometry with just the right amount of symmetry to allow for large interesting moduli spaces with mysterious but tractable behavior. Other geometries, such as affine geometry and pseudo-Riemannian hyperbolic geometry, were studied as well.

 

Some highlights of the intellectual merit include:

 

The PI continued joint work with F. Gueritaud and F. Kassel  studying a new notion of convex cocompactness in real projective space. This notion describes certain discrete subgroups of the projective general linear group that behave like convex cocompact subgroups of hyperbolic space (in the classical sense) but can also demonstrate some non-hyperbolic behavior. Weisman, A Ph.D. student of the PI who was partially supported by this award, gave a beautiful characterization, in terms of limit sets, of relatively hyperbolic convex cocompact groups in projective space.

In joint work of Gueritaud, Kassel, Lee, and Marquis, the PI characterized all linear reflection group representations of Coxeter groups which are convex cocompact in projective space. Hence a direct result of this award is that the study of convex cocompactness in projective space has progressed substantially both in terms of theory and new examples. 

 

Joint with F. Bonsante, S. Maloni, and J.-M. Schlenker, the PI continued studying three-dimensional hyperbolic geometry, three-dimensional anti de Sitter geometry and their connections with the goal of resolving Thurston?s bending conjecture, in the setting of hyperbolic manifolds, and of Mess?s analogous conjecture, in the setting of anti de Sitter manifolds. This joint work resolved the existence part of universal versions of the two conjectures. 

 

The PI also continued joint work with Ballas, Lee, and Marquis on a recent project that studies exotic real projective Dehn fillings of a finite volume hyperbolic three-manifold. The project develops a surprising analogue of Thurston's theory of hyperbolic Dehn fillings which finds that for some Dehn fillings, there is a second non-hyperbolic convex real projective structure, in addition to the hyperbolic structure. 

 

The broader impacts of this award include disseminating the results to the mathematical community at conferences and seminars and training Ph.D. students in topics of the project. The PI advised seven graduate students at various stages throughout the award. Four of those students graduated and went on to research postdocs, while the other three are still working toward their degrees. The PI also mentored one postdoc.
